newsitem.title: JAPAN: Nikko says may fall short of 96/97 profit forecast.
newsitem.headline: Nikko says may fall short of 96/97 profit forecast.

text.p: Japan's third biggest brokerage, Nikko Securities Co Ltd, said on Friday that it was not optimistic about achieving its earnings forecast for the current business year ending in March.
Nikko executive vice president Masao Yuki, speaking in an interview with Reuters, cited falling stock prices as the reason for his lack of optimism on earnings.

"While we have two more months before the end of the current business year, we cannot be optimistic (about the target)," he said. "It is becoming difficult to achieve the figures which we revised (last December) because (monthly) earnings have not reached the level that we had anticipated since December."

He also said that the abolition of Japan's securities transaction tax, as urged by some politicians and officials, would help Japan's stock market, which has been stuck recently in a downward spiral on fears about the economy.
Yuki also said that "Big Bang" reforms aimed at liberalising Japan's financial markets by 2001 will trigger a kind of "survival contest" whose winners will remain in the market.
"(To be a winner) we must cut costs and raise the efficiency of all types of assets," he said.

Yuki said that the most important issue for Nikko before the Big Bang reforms was how to cut total personnel costs but raise payments to talented young workers with a bright future ahead of them, without hurting morale.
Last December Nikko revised its earnings forecast for the year to March 31 downward to a parent current profit of 40 billion yen from a previous forecast of 60 billion yen.

At the same time it said it expects a net loss of 95 billion yen compared with the previous forecast of a net profit of 24 billion yen because it decided to post an extraordinary loss of 147.5 billion yen in order to provide financial aid to troubled financial affiliates.
Yuki said, however, that the impact of falling stock prices would be less harsh for securities companies than for the banking industry.
If the Nikkei share average falls to the 17,000 level and stays there, the banks would have trouble achieving their problem loan write-off plans, he said.
Nikko's Yuki also said that banks are keen to sell shares in securities houses with which they have no close business ties, and such unwinding of cross-shareholdings would continue.
